questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhoea, unintentional weight loss, joint pain, pallor, and generalised weakness. Upper GI endoscopy and biopsy revealed characteristic histopathological findings suggestive of Whipple's disease. Which of the following histopathological features would have led to the diagnosis?

choices.text: Foamy macrophages filled with PAS-positive granules
Villous atrophy and blunting of the small intestinal mucosa
Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate in the lamina propria
Presence of caseating granulomas and acid-fast bacilli

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Foamy macrophages filled with PAS-positive granules

Explanation:

Whipple's disease is a malabsorption problem: Nothing will get absorbed from the intestine, especially fats, leading to Steatorrhea.

 

Whipple’s disease:

Feature

Explanation

Pathogen
  • Tropheryma whipplei (actinomycete) (Gram positive bacteria)

Symptoms
  • Diarrhoea (due to impaired lymphatic drainage), weight loss, and arthralgia.
  • Others: arthritis, fever, lymphadenopathy, neurologic, cardiac, or pulmonary involvement

Histology

Characterised by foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria, which contain periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant granules, representing partially digested bacteria within lysosomes
Diagnosis PCR is a better diagnosis than biopsy

 

Villous atrophy and blunting of the small intestinal mucosa (Option B): Seen in celiac disease or gluten sensitivity

Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate in the lamina propria (Option C): Seen in TB

Presence of caseating granulomas and acid-fast bacilli (Option D): Seen in Crohn's disease

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhoea, abdominal bloating, and unintended weight loss. She reports discomfort after consuming gluten-containing foods. Laboratory tests show elevated tissue transglutaminase (tTG) and anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA) levels, prompting a small intestinal biopsy via upper endoscopy. Which of the following combinations of histopathological features will be seen in this condition?


	Intraepithelial CD8+ T Lymphocytes
	Crypt hyperplasia
	Villous atrophy
	Decreased mitotic activity
	Inflammatory cell infiltration in lamina propria
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3, 5

Explanation:

The clinical scenario is classic for Celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion, confirmed by:

  • Positive anti-tTG and anti-EMA antibodies

  • Small bowel biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis

Marsh criteria of celiac disease: Because the antibodies are formed due to consumption of gluten, they first attack the villi of intestine (Villous atrophy)

Histopathological features in Celiac disease:

Feature Seen in Celiac? Explanation
1. Intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes Yes Early and sensitive marker of immune response
2. Crypt hyperplasia Yes Compensatory response due to villous damage
3. Villous atrophy Yes Hallmark feature; leads to malabsorption
4. Decreased mitotic activity No Mitotic activity is increased because of increased inflammation and proliferation, not decreased
5. Inflammatory cell infiltration in LP Yes Mainly lymphocytes and plasma cells in lamina propria

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of chronic abdominal pain and diarrhoea, worsening notably after consuming wheat-based foods. Physical examination reveals signs suggestive of malabsorption. Considering celiac disease as a possible diagnosis, which of the following statements regarding its pathogenesis is NOT correct?

choices.text: Gliadin peptides in the lamina propria are deamidated by tissue transglutaminase.
HLA-DR2 or HLA-DR8 significantly influences celiac disease susceptibility.
Gliadin peptides may induce epithelial cells to express IL-15, activating CD8+ lymphocytes.
Type 1 diabetes, Sjögren syndrome, and IgA nephropathy are associated with celiac disease.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HLA-DR2 or HLA-DR8 significantly influences celiac disease susceptibility.

Explanation:

Celiac disease (aka celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy) is an immune-mediated condition triggered by consuming foods containing gluten, such as barley, rye, oats, and wheat.

It is influenced by HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8, not HLA-DR2 or HLA-DR8

Gliadin is released when these patient consumes gluten.

 

Pathogenesis of Celiac disease:

Gliadin peptides

↓

Deamidated by Tissue transglutaminase (TTG) enzyme of intestine

↓

IL-15 expression

↓

CD8+ t-lymphocytes activated

↓

Epithelial damage

 

Genetic variations may link celiac disease to other immune disorders, such as type 1 diabetes, thyroiditis, Sjogren syndrome, and IgA nephropathy. (Option D)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female who recently returned from a tropical region presents with persistent diarrhoea, weight loss, fatigue, anaemia, and vitamin deficiencies, along with a small intestine biopsy findings of villous atrophy and chronic mucosal inflammation. Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is typically NOT affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Colon

Explanation:

The clinical scenario, with a history of returning from a tropical region and biopsy findings, points towards diagnosing Tropical enteropathy or Environmental enteropathy that does not affect the colon.

This disease often occurs after E. coli infection.

Tropical sprue:

  • Predominantly affects the small intestine( duodenum, jejunum, and ileum) and presents with Iron deficiency anemia or megaloblastic anemia.

Part of the small intestine

Nutrient absorbed

Duodenum

Iron

Jejunum

Folic acid

Ileum

Vitamin B12

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with failure to thrive, chronic diarrhoea, and poor weight gain. A peripheral blood smear revealed a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. Biochemical investigations reveal very low levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MTTP gene mutation

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear findings suggest Abetalipoproteinemia, caused by a mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP), which is required for the transfer of lipids to nascent apolipoprotein B polypeptide in the endoplasmic reticulum.

Abetalipoproteinemia:

Aetiology
  • Mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP)

Presentation
  • Extremely low cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins.
  • Intestine shows lipid vacuoles because of problem in lipid transfer.
Biochemical investigation
  • Low triglyceride cholesterol levels
  • Low fat soluble vitamin levels

Symptoms
  • Presents in infancy with failure to thrive, diarrhoea, and steatorrhea.

Peripheral smear
  • Presence of acanthocytes-RBCs with peripheral spikes

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents with severe watery diarrhoea and failure to thrive since birth. Stool studies are negative for pathogens. A small bowel biopsy shows villous atrophy, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies within enterocytes, and reduction of microvilli on the enterocyte surface. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is characterised by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal part of the colon.
It is associated with mutations in the MYO5B or STX3 genes.
Histological findings include villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia.
It is commonly caused by rotavirus infection, which leads to persistent diarrhoea.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is associated with mutations in the MYO5B or STX3 genes.

Explanation:

The clinical presentation suggests Microvillous Inclusion Disease (MVID).

  • It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterised by severe, intractable watery diarrhoea from early infancy.
  • It presents with inclusion bodies and reduction in microvilli.
  • Aetiology: Mutations in the MYO5B or STX3 genes.

It is characterised by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal part of the colon (Option A): Seen in Hirschsprung disease.

Histological findings include villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia (Option C): Seen in celiac disease or gluten insensitivity.

It is commonly caused by rotavirus infection, which leads to persistent diarrhoea (Option D): Stool studies are negative for pathogen in this case.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with foul-smelling, greasy diarrhoea, bloating, and abdominal cramps following a hiking trip in a remote area. Stool microscopy reveals cysts containing motile trophozoites. A duodenal biopsy shows luminal organisms, as shown in the image, without tissue invasion. Based on the clinical presentation and biopsy findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Giardia lamblia

Explanation:

The scenario is of Giardia lamblia infestation

Giardia lamblia:

Definition
  • Flagellated protozoan parasite
  • Commonly associated with contaminated water sources.

Symptoms
  • Foul-smelling-greasy diarrhoea
  • Bloating
  • Abdominal cramps.

Biopsy findings
  • Luminal organisms attached to the intestinal epithelium
  • Blunting of the villi and
  • inflammation without tissue invasion.

 
  • Giardia trophozoites on biopsy are often described as resembling "falling leaves"

Cryptosporidium (Option A)

  • Coccidian parasite
  • Usually present along brush border of the intestine.
  • Causes watery diarrhoea, especially in immunocompromised individuals

Tropheryma whipplei (Option B)

  • Causes Whipple's disease
  • Histology: PAS-positive foamy macrophages in the intestinal mucosa

Entamoeba histolytica (Option C)

  • Protozoan parasite
  • It causes amoebic ulcer in intestine identified by flask shaped ulcers.

questions.text: Which type of ulcer is characterised by multiple punched-out ulcers with undermined edges and necrotic bases on histopathological examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amoebic ulcer

Explanation:

On histopathological examination, amoebic ulcers caused by Entamoeba histolytica present as multiple punched-out ulcers with undermined edges and necrotic bases (flask-shaped ulcers). The ulcers often have surrounding inflammation and contain trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica.

  • When Entamoeba histolytica goes to liver: It breaks the liver tissue into brown coloured pus known as Encovy sauce appearance

TB ulcer (Option A): Transverse ulcer in direction.

Typhoid ulcer (Option B): Longitudinal ulcer in direction.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with severe diarrhoea and abdominal pain after completing a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics for a respiratory infection. Stool studies detect the presence of Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile) toxin. A colonoscopy revealed diffuse yellowish plaques covering the colonic mucosa, as shown in the image. Which inflammatory cell type predominantly infiltrates the lamina propria and surface epithelium in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neutrophils

Explanation:

The given clinical condition suggests Pseudomembranous enterocolitis (PMEC).

  • Pseudomembranous: On colonoscopy, diffuse yellowish plaques covering the colonic mucosa are seen.
  • Enterocolitis: Inflammation of intestine
  • Long term antibiotics alters the gut flora and makes person prone to C. difficile infection, which damages the intestine and forms pseudomembrane.
    • Necrosis and damaged cells are always associated with neutrophilic infiltrations (Option C)
  •  Patient presents with watery diarrhoea (rarely can present with bloody diarrhoea),
  • Caused by 2 toxins of C. difficile: Toxin A and Toxin B
  • On biopsy: Classical volcano like erruptions
  • Drug of choice: Vancomycin ± Metronidazole
    • New drug: Fidaxomicin

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with chronic abdominal pain, diarrhoea, weight loss, and occasional blood in the stool. A colonoscopy reveals patchy erythema, oedema, and shallow ulcers with intervening normal mucosa in the terminal ileum and colon. The histopathological findings from the affected area are shown below. What histopathological features are observed in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Smooth transition between ulcerated and adjacent normal mucosa
Absence of metaplastic changes in the epithelium
Uniform distribution of inflammation throughout the affected areas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Presence of noncaseating granulomas

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings showing noncaseating granulomas and skip lesions suggest Crohn’s disease.

  • Noncaseating granulomas are round lesions with multinucleated giant cells within them.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and weight loss. A colonoscopy reveals findings consistent with Crohn's diseaseWhat histological features would you observe in this patient's biopsy?

choices.text: Ulcers can extend beyond the mucosa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer:D) Ulcers can extend beyond the mucosa

Explanation:

  • Crohn’s disease presents with transmural inflammation, which causes deep ulcers.
  • It is characterised by transmural inflammation and can affect the entire intestinal wall thickness, from the mucosa to the serosa, which can lead to fissures and fistulas. (Option A ruled out)
  • Strictures or fibrosis are commonly seen in this condition (Option B ruled out)
  • Ulcers are intially superficial and then goes deep extending to every layer of intestine. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which statement is true regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) pathogenesis?

choices.text: NOD2 polymorphisms are closely associated with Crohn's disease in Asian populations.
ATG16L1 mutation promotes ATG16L1 degradation and enhances autophagy.
Dysbiosis is often established at disease presentation in IBD.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dysbiosis is often established at disease presentation in IBD.

Explanation:

"Dysbiosis" refers to an imbalance in the gut microbiota characterised by shifts in microbial populations and reduced species diversity.

  • This imbalance is commonly observed at the onset of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
  • Dysbiosis can lead to alterations in the gut environment, including increased inflammation and impaired barrier function, which may contribute to the progression of IBD.

 

NOD2 polymorphisms are closely associated with Crohn's disease in Asian populations (Option A)

NOD2 polymorphisms are closely associated with Crohn's disease but not with Crohn's disease in Asian populations.

ATG16L1 mutation promotes ATG16L1 degradation and enhances autophagy (Option B)

The ATG16L1 mutation limits autophagy rather than enhancing it by promoting ATG16L1 degradation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease is true?

choices.text: Ulcerative colitis is characterised by skip lesions, whereas Crohn’s disease typically presents with continuous inflammation.
Cobblestone appearance is a feature seen in ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease but is more commonly associated with Crohn's disease.
Ulcerative colitis typically begins in the rectum and extends proximally, whereas Crohn's disease can involve any part of the GI tract.
Fistulae, strictures, and abscesses are more commonly seen in ulcerative colitis than in Crohn's disease.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ulcerative colitis typically begins in the rectum and extends proximally, whereas Crohn's disease can involve any part of the GI tract.

Explanation:

 

 

Features

Ulcerative colitis

Crohn’s disease

Location

 Typically begins in the rectum and extends proximally affecting entire large and small intestines: Backwash ileitis

Can involve any part of the GI tract: Primarily it starts most commonly from Ileum and then it can effect any part of GI tract in the forn of skip lesions.

Distribution

Diffused continuous lesion

Patchy, with skip lesions. (Option A)

Gross appearance
  • Mucosal erythema and granularity
  • Broad-based ulcers with a continuous pattern
  • Pseudopolyps
  • Mucosal atrophy
  • Smooth, continuous inflammation
  • Transmural inflammation
  • Aphthous ulcers
  • Cobblestone appearance (Option B)
  • Fistulae, strictures, abscesses
  • Creeping fat (mesenteric fat wrapping)

Complications
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Colonic dilation
  • Mucosal bridges.
  • Strictures
  • Fistulae
  • Fissures (Option D)

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a 5-day history of non-bloody, watery diarrhea. He reports that he recently returned from a hiking trip in a rural area where he drank water from a nearby stream. On examination, he appears dehydrated but is otherwise stable. A stool sample was sent for analysis, which revealed the presence of oocysts. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:A) Cryptosporidium

Explanation:

Cryptosporidiosis is a significant cause of diarrhea worldwide. Cryptosporidium is known to cause non-bloody, watery diarrhea and is commonly associated with drinking contaminated water, particularly from untreated sources such as streams or lakes. The presence of oocysts in the stool supports this diagnosis

  • C. hominis and C. parvum usually presents with waterry diarrhea and many times the patient is immunocompromised like HIV+.
  • Oocysts are present in stool and measures 4-6µm.
  • Cold ZN stain or Kinyoun stain is used to see oocytes.
  • On biopsy of intestine, Cryptosporidium is found along the brush border of epithelium.

Microsporidium (Option B): Rarely presents with oocysts in stool sample.

Giardia lamblia (Option C): Do not have oocysts.

Entamoeba histolytica (Option D): Do not have oocysts.
